steps.title: Keys
steps.text:
Key markers are introduced in this expansion. These stand for important objects or information that the players can get at and which you can use during the scenarios.
Key markers have two sides. On their back (hidden side) all 7 keys have the same universal key symbol. This allows them to be shuffled at random, without the investigators knowing which marker is which is. Each key is on the front (open side) coded with its own color.
If 1 or more keys are used in a scenario, the Scenario Setup instructions indicate how many keys needed and whether these are shuffled face down or face up be put aside. Keys can be through various card effects to join the game. Most of the time they are doing it on an opponent, a place or a story advantage card. An investigator can participate in 3 ways Key:

bullets.text: In case a place with a key on it no longer indicates itself an investigator can take control of everyone as a [fast] ability Pick up the key at this location.

In case an investigator hits an opponent with a key on it brings to exit the game, that investigator must be in control of take over every key that opponent had on him. (If a such opponent otherwise leaves the game become the keys placed on its place.)
Some card effects can allow an investigator to do the Take control of keys in other ways.

steps.example: As soon as an investigator takes control of a key, the Token flipped face down (if it is face down) and placed on his investigator card. If an investigator who controls 1 or more keys, is eliminated from the game, each of his keys is placed in his place. An investigator may use any number of his keys as a [action] ability give to another investigator at the same location. Keys do not have an independent game effect. Some card effects but can change depending on which keys an investigator controls. Sometimes keys are also needed to progress in a scenario.

steps.title: Flood Tokens
steps.text: In the course of this campaign it can happen that locations are flooded by scenario map effects. Each place has 1 of 3 different ones Flood levels: A place is either not flooded, partially flooded, or completely flooded. The tide level of a place can be double sided in this one Extension included flood markers are displayed. The tide level one Place has no independent game effect. Some card effects can but change or get stronger as long as an investigator is on you flooded place, especially if the place is completely flooded. A place without a flood marker it is not flooded.

bullets.text: If a location is partially flooded, place a flood marker with the "Partially flooded" side on top to indicate this.
If a place is completely flooded, a flood marker with the “Fully flooded ”side up (or the flood marker is if the place is already partially flooded) to indicate this.

If the flood level of a location is "increased", it changes from "not flooded" to "partially flooded" or from "partially flooded" to "Completely flooded". If the place is completely flooded, the high tide level can no longer be increased.

If the flood level of a location is "lowered", it changes from "completely flooded" to "partially flooded" or from "partially flooded" to "Not flooded". When a place is no longer flooded, its flood marker becomes away.
Both partially flooded places and completely flooded places count in Referring to card effects as "flooded".
